Bessette v. Bessette, 390 Mass. 543 (198.raw_text: Bessette v. Bessette, 390 Mass. 543 (1983) (trial court’s broad discretion in custody determinations and modifications focused on best interests of the child).
Bessette v. Bessette, 390 Mass. 543 (198.proposition: 7. Bessette v. Bessette, 390 Mass. 543 (1983) (trial court’s broad discretion in custody determinations and modifications focused on best interests of the child).
Bessette v. Bessette, 390 Mass. 543 (198.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Bessette v. Bessette and does not concern custody determinations or modifications. It is a medical malpractice/informed consent case (discussing Harnish and retroactivity) and nowhere addresses family law, child custody, or trial court discretion in that context. Therefore it cannot support the proposition about broad trial court discretion in custody matters focused on the child’s best interests.
Bessette v. Bessette, 390 Mass. 543 (198.relevant_excerpt: Although the doctrine of informed consent has existed in various forms since Justice (then Judge) Cardozo’s sweeping assertion of it in 1914, Schloendorff v. Society of the N. Y. Hosp., 211 N.Y. 125 (1914), overruled on other grounds, Bing v. Thunig, 2 N.Y.2d 656 (1957), Massachusetts courts have not expressed an opinion either in support of or against the doctrine until relatively recently. In Harnish v. Children’s Hosp. Medical Center, 387 Mass. 152 (1982), which was decided after the tribunal’s ruling, we explicitly endorsed the doctrine for the first time...

Brown v. Brown, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 70 (19.raw_text: Brown v. Brown, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 70 (1995).
Brown v. Brown, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 70 (19.proposition: 8. Custody modification precedent recognizing the need for proof of material change and assessment of best interests: e.g., Brown v. Brown, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 70 (1995).
Brown v. Brown, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 70 (19.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts criminal case involving drug distribution, jury instructions on prior inconsistent statements, and sentencing under G.L. c. 94C, § 32A. It does not involve family law, custody, or any standards for custody modification such as material change in circumstances or best interests of the child. Thus, it cannot serve as precedent for the custody modification proposition claimed; the citation appears to be to a different Brown v. Brown case than the one excerpted here.
Brown v. Brown, 39 Mass. App. Ct. 70 (19.relevant_excerpt: The jury returned a guilty verdict against the defendant on an indictment charging that she “did knowingly or intentionally manufacture, distribute, or dispense a controlled substance in CLASS B, to wit: COCAINE.” On appeal, she claims the trial judge erred in failing to give a requested instruction on the use of prior inconsistent statements for assessing the credibility of a witness, in giving an instruction to the jury that they were not to consider the quality of the arresting officer’s police report in determining their verdict, and in ruling that the mandatory minimum sentence under G. L. c. 94C, § 32A(c), applied to the indictment.

Santos v. Santos, 420 Mass. 365 (1995)..proposition: 9. Cases recognizing parental behavior and interference with parenting time as relevant to custody and modification: e.g., Santos v. Santos, 420 Mass. 365 (1995).
Santos v. Santos, 420 Mass. 365 (1995)..case_name: Griffith v. New England Telephone & Telegraph Co.
Santos v. Santos, 420 Mass. 365 (1995)..support_reasoning: This is not Santos v. Santos and it does not concern custody, parenting time, or parental interference. The opinion is Griffith v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co., dealing with liability for oil contamination under Mass. Gen. Laws c. 21E. It therefore cannot support a proposition about parental behavior being relevant to custody or modification proceedings.
Santos v. Santos, 420 Mass. 365 (1995)..relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiffs’ action under G. L. c. 21E (1992 ed.), the Massachusetts Oil and Hazardous Material Release Prevention Act, against the defendant was previously before us... We now reverse." (entire opinion concerns statutory liability for environmental contamination, not family law or custody).

Kelly v. Kelly, 441 Mass. 286 (2004)..proposition: 10. Cases discussing parental alienation, disparagement and their impact on custody decisions: e.g., Kelly v. Kelly, 441 Mass. 286 (2004).
Kelly v. Kelly, 441 Mass. 286 (2004)..support_reasoning: The case is a criminal statutory-interpretation decision about the Massachusetts incest statute and the meaning of “consanguinity.” It does not involve a custody dispute, parental alienation, or disparagement between parents, nor does it discuss how such conduct impacts custody determinations. Using Kelly v. Kelly, 441 Mass. 286 (2004), as authority on parental alienation or custody is therefore inaccurate.
Kelly v. Kelly, 441 Mass. 286 (2004)..relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that ‘consanguinity’ is a necessary element of the crime of incest, and that the incest statute makes criminal only relationships between persons related by blood or adoption, not other relationships prohibited by the marriage statute, G. L. c. 207, §§ 1 and 2… [T]he necessary element of consanguinity was absent.”

Foley v. Foley, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1.raw_text: Foley v. Foley, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1998).
Foley v. Foley, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1.proposition: 11. Decisions addressing the need for clarity in parental decision-making for extracurricular activities and scheduling disputes: e.g., Foley v. Foley, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1998).
Foley v. Foley, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal drug-trafficking and search-and-seizure case. It does not involve family law, custody, parental decision-making, or disputes over children’s extracurricular activities or scheduling. The proposition misattributes Foley v. Foley as authority on parenting decision-making; the case provides no such discussion or holding.
Foley v. Foley, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1.relevant_excerpt: A jury in Superior Court convicted the defendant of trafficking on October 27, 1994, in more than twenty-eight grams of heroin, G. L. c. 94C, § 32E(c)(2). He appeals, arguing that a judge erred in denying his pretrial motion to suppress the evidence of 1,494 bags of heroin found during the search of an automobile he was driving at the time. He claims that he was arrested without probable cause before the search and that the police searched the vehicle without a warrant or probable cause to believe they would find drugs therein.

Rivera v. Rivera, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 261.raw_text: Rivera v. Rivera, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 261 (1999).
Rivera v. Rivera, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 261.proposition: 12. Cases recognizing the court’s authority to order evaluations and mental-health services for children affected by parental conflict: e.g., Rivera v. Rivera, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 261 (1999).
Rivera v. Rivera, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 261.support_reasoning: The quoted opinion is a Massachusetts criminal appeal about sufficiency of evidence for possession of heroin with intent to distribute and related sentencing enhancement issues. It does not involve family law, children, parental conflict, or the court’s authority to order evaluations or mental-health services for children. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about court-ordered evaluations and mental-health services for children affected by parental conflict; it appears to be a miscitation or wrong Rivera case.
Rivera v. Rivera, 47 Mass. App. Ct. 261.relevant_excerpt: On December 19, 1996, a Superior Court jury returned a verdict of guilty against Gonzalez of possession of heroin with intent to distribute (G. L. c. 94C, § 32[a]). That day he was also convicted, at a second trial before the same judge and jury, of having committed that offense at least once before (G. L. c. 94C, § 32[6]) and was sentenced to serve a single, enhanced sentence of five years at M.C.I., Cedar Junction. … We affirm.

Smith v. Smith, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (199.raw_text: Smith v. Smith, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1994).
Smith v. Smith, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (199.proposition: 13. Precedent discussing the standard for modification (material change in circumstances affecting welfare of child): e.g., Smith v. Smith, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (1994).
Smith v. Smith, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (199.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about Batson/Soares challenges and peremptory strikes based on race. It does not concern family law, child custody, or the standard for modification based on a material change in circumstances affecting the welfare of a child. The proposition mis-cites this Smith v. Smith decision, so the case does not support the claimed modification standard.
Smith v. Smith, 36 Mass. App. Ct. 1 (199.relevant_excerpt: The sole question on appeal is the adequacy of the prosecutor’s expressed reasons for her challenges. The familiar standards for reviewing such adequacy can be easily stated, if not applied. “While [the prosecutor] need not approximate the grounds required by a challenge for cause, [her] reason must pertain to the individual qualities of the prospective juror and not to that juror’s group association.” Commonwealth v. Soares, 377 Mass. at 491.

Davis v. Davis, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (2.raw_text: Davis v. Davis, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (2001).
Davis v. Davis, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (2.proposition: 14. Authority on enforcement of non-disparagement and parental conduct provisions as part of custody orders: e.g., Davis v. Davis, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (2001).
Davis v. Davis, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (2.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts criminal appeal (Commonwealth v. Moore), dealing with a defendant’s right to testify, jury instructions, voice inflection, and discharge of a deliberating juror. It does not involve family law, custody orders, or any non-disparagement or parental conduct provisions. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority on enforcement of non-disparagement or parental conduct terms in custody orders, and the citation to Davis v. Davis, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (2001), is not reflected in this text at all.
Davis v. Davis, 52 Mass. App. Ct. 123 (2.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion in this opinion of custody, domestic relations, non-disparagement clauses, or parental conduct provisions; the case exclusively addresses criminal trial issues such as the defendant’s right to testify, jury instructions (including on self-defense), voice inflection, and juror discharge.
